$$
\sigma(A)=\operatorname*{inf}_{n=1,2,3,\ldots}{\frac{A(n)}{n}}.

Clearly,

0\leq\sigma(A)\leq1

for every set  $A$  of integers.If  $\sigma(A)=\alpha$  ,then

forall  $n=1,2,3,\ldots.\,\mathrm{If}\;1\notin A$  ,then  $A(1)=0$  andso  $\pmb{\sigma}(\pmb{A})=\pmb{0}$  
If A contains every positive integer,then  $A(n)=n$  for all  $n\geq1$  andso  $\sigma(A)=1$  If  $m\not\in A$  forsome  $m\geq1$  ,then  $A(m)\leq m-1$  and 

$$

Thus,  $\sigma(A)=1$  if and only if  $A$  contains every positive integer.
